article.description: Heralded Connecticut freshman  Charlie Villanueva checked into the game after Army checked out.
article.headline: Villanueva makes debut for UConn
article.story: STORRS, Conn. (AP) -- The new kid provided some excitement for Connecticut while the reliable veteran did what he does best. Charlie Villanueva scored 16 points in his college debut while Emeka Okafor recorded the fourth triple-double in Connecticut history to lead the third-ranked Huskies past Army 74-46 Saturday night. Okafor picked up the first triple-double of his career by finishing with 18 points, 15 rebounds and a career-high 10 blocks. He joined Donyell Marshall, Doron Sheffer and Caron Butler as the only Huskies to have triple-doubles. The 6-foot-10 junior center also matched Marshall for the school record for blocks in a game. "The triple-double by Emeka was a long time coming," UConn coach Jim Calhoun said. The game also marked the highly anticipated debut of Villanueva, who missed the first six games and both exhibition games while the NCAA determined his eligibility. He also had five rebounds and three blocks. The packed student section broke into chants of "Charlie! Charlie!" when the 6-11 freshman stepped on the court for the shootaround about an hour before tipoff. "The fans have been supporting me a long way. It just felt good being out there and helping my team out," Villanueva said. The eligibility issue stemmed from Villanueva's workouts in front of NBA scouts last summer. NCAA rules state that the recruit, a family member or friend not related to basketball must pay all expenses for such workouts. After an investigation that stretched into several weeks, the NCAA cleared him to play on Friday. Villanueva bolstered an already tough frontcourt for UConn, which includes Okafor, 6-10 freshman Josh Boone and 6-11 reserve Hilton Anderson. "He's another force out there, another problem for our opponents to worry about," Okafor said. The Huskies (6-1) controlled the paint the entire game against the smaller Black Knights (3-4), who were playing back-to-back games for the first time in six years. Army lost 68-62 at Albany on Friday night. Kenny Doleac and Adeniyi Amadou each had nine points for Army, which trailed 39-15 at halftime. Army conceded nearly every offensive rebound against UConn in order to hustle five guys back on defense to guard the lane. "We wanted them to take outside shots and we tried to pressure as much as we could, but it was tough," Army coach Jim Crews said. The Cadets even conceded the opening tip, sending in 6-foot Marshall Jackson to jump against Okafor, who easily directed the ball to a teammate. "That kind of threw me off," Okafor said. "I was wondering 'What if the guys wins the tip?" The Huskies rejected just about everything the Black Knights could muster inside early, holding them scoreless the first eight minutes of the game. "The one constant we had tonight was the fact we continued to play defense," Calhoun said. "When you ask the team to come out and play defense, then you're doing exactly what the coach has asked you to do." The Huskies outrebounded the Black Knights 53-31 and finished with a 38-20 scoring advantage in the paint. More than 8,000 fans braved the winter storm, nearly filling the 10,167-seat Gampel Pavilion. Villanueva said he enjoyed his 22 minutes on the floor but admitted there's plenty of room for improvement. "This was a good game to break me into. I've got to get in game shape," Villanueva said. "I know I'm going to be fine. Now that I'm playing, you just feel a lot better."
